Trident has an embarrasing problem they want us to solve. As strange as it is, some of those Plasmid creatures have stolen a Trident Ship.

Seriously? Plasmids? Those gurgling puddle aliens?
Seriously? Plasmids? Those gurgling puddle sentients?
You've got it. Uncharacteristically, they managed to sneak onboard, snuff out the crew, and are joyriding throughout the universe.

Why doesn't Trident take care of this problem themselves? Why bother hiring us?

We've got the reputation of being able to handle such things. This wasn't just any ship, it was a prototype modified Trident Battlecruiser.

Ah, from the rumors I've heard, Trident would stand to lose face if they let any other megacorporation know they lost an important ship to some Plasmids.

Exactly. In addition to a PSI-Weapon of some power, we will be rewarded with the plans for this vessel. Trident is abandoning the model after this incident.

Nice, so where are these Plasmid Joyriders? Let's get them.
Nice, so where are these Plasmid Joyriders? Let's handle this.
It won't be so easy, I'm afraid. Trident has given us a list of planets and moons we need to go to in order to deal with the Plasmids.

What is the problem? Why not go and wipe them out?
What is the problem? Why not go and destroy the ship?
First, we'll need to pay someone to give us the general area where the Plasmids were last seen. Second, they've got an advanced cloaking device.

Please don't tell me there's a "third."

Heh, "third," they will try to use an advanced jump-engine to escape. It is impossible to tell where they will jump to.

Then how could we possibly find them?

To uncloak them, we will disperse some virtual marbles into space and see where they bounce off of an invisible craft.

Alright, continue.

Then to prevent recloaking, we will use a jamming device to prevent such a tactic.

Sounds expensive, but alright.

Finally to follow them wherever they jump, we will need an improbability drive. The odds of randomly jumping to the exact location they jumped to is very remote.

I think I read about one of these in an ancient handheld database. . .

An improbability drive would, when activated, jump to the exact location they did simply because it is so unlikely. Then we fight them before they jump again.

Geez. I guess we'd better get going to these locations to purchase all that we'll need. Where do we go first?
